title: 110_s2949
content: The Act may be cited as the "Mark O. Hatfield Scholarship and Excellence in Tribal Governance Act of 2008". Congress acknowledges Senator Mark O. Hatfield's significant contributions to Native American rights and tribal self-governance, leading to the establishment of programs in his name to promote excellence in tribal government. The Act defines key terms such as Board, eligible individual, Foundation, Institute, Institute Policy Board, and institution of higher education. The term "institution of higher education" is defined in the Higher Education Act of 1965. The term "State" includes various entities such as states, territories, and commonwealths. Establishment of the Mark O. Hatfield Scholarship and Excellence in Tribal Governance Foundation. The Mark O. Hatfield Scholarship and Excellence in Tribal Governance Foundation is established as an independent entity in the Executive branch with a Board of Trustees overseeing its operations in Portland, Oregon. An Executive Director appointed by the Board will serve as the chief executive officer and carry out the Foundation's functions. The Executive Director of the Foundation, under the supervision of the Board, may receive compensation at the rate specified for an employee in level IV of the Executive Schedule. The Foundation's purposes include training tribal council members, promoting understanding of tribal self-government, addressing critical issues facing tribal governments, conducting research on tribal governance, and providing educational outreach. The Foundation, in consultation with the Institute, may conduct programs, activities, and services to carry out its purposes. This includes awarding scholarships, fellowships, internships, and grants, as well as organizing national competitions to select recipients. Eligible individuals may receive scholarships, fellowships, internships, and grants from the Foundation. The Foundation offers scholarships, fellowships, and grants to eligible individuals for study in tribal governance fields. Recipients are named "Mark O. Hatfield Scholars." Scholarships are awarded to undergraduate students pursuing careers in tribal governance or tribal public policy. Payments are made to eligible individuals under this Act. The Foundation may require reports from eligible individuals awarded scholarships under this Act, containing necessary information and filed at specified times. The Foundation may award fellowships to outstanding graduate students and faculty in fields related to tribal governance, public policy, law, or medicine. Recipients must show satisfactory progress in their studies and devote full time to research. Additionally, internships may be awarded to deserving individuals. The Foundation may award internships to deserving individuals for use in participating in Federal, State, and local agencies or major tribal governance organizations, as well as Native American and Alaska Native individuals for internships in public health or public policy organizations. Additionally, the Foundation shall award grants to the Institute for various purposes related to tribal governance and public policy issues. The Foundation assists in developing a tribal governance research program at the Institute, determining program priorities and allocating funds. At least 50% of funds go to specific programs, while 20% is allocated to the Institute for subsections (h) and (i). The Foundation provides funding for tribal governance research programs at the Institute, with a 25-percent matching share required from non-Federal sources. Adequate space must be provided at the Institute for the Executive Director and staff, and not more than 15 percent of funds can be used for salaries and administrative purposes. Authorization of appropriations is granted to carry out this Act.
